question: Where the hell have you been? Mom, come on and eat.
Then why'd I cook!
answer: I don't know why you cooked! I don't know why you bother!

question: Say something.
What?
Kiss my ass.
Centuries ago it had an 'e' at the end.
Nowhere in particular. I go where I will and I do what I must. That's why I'm in trouble. I'm sort've what you might call... 'in exile'.
An honest man is always in trouble, Simon. Remember that.
answer: How do you know my name? I am not retarded.

question: Well... I'll take your word for that.
answer: People. I mean. They think. You know. Because.

question: I see. Here. Take this. And... ...this. Keep them with you at all times. You ever feel like you got something to say and you can't get it out, stop and write it down. OK?
This? This is my life's work. My memoirs. My 'Confession'.

I've been bad. Repeatedly. But why brag? The details of my exploits are only a pretext for a far more expansive consideration of general truths. What is this? It's a philosophy. A poetics. A politics, if you will. A literature of protest. A novel of ideas. A pornographic magazine of truly comic-book proportions. It is, in the end, whatever the hell I want it to be. And when I'm through with it, it's gunna blow a hole this wide straight through the world's own idea of itself! Come on, let's go break their arms!

Once. I forget where I was. Central America maybe. Somewhere hot. Stupid job. Bad pay. Dangerous location and water so foul the natives wouldn't even piss in it. This crowd of drunken motherfuckers hired by the local drug cartel shows up at my hotel room and threatens to tear me limb from limb. And I say, listen, hombres, OK, you've got me outnumbered four to one and you're gunna kill me here tonight and not a soul in this dimly lit world is ever gunna notice I'm gone. Fine. But one of you... one of you... one of you is gunna have his eye torn out. Period. Silence. I repeat myself. One of you poor, underpaid jerks is gunna have an eye ripped out of its socket. I promise. It's a small thing, perhaps, all things considered. But I will succeed. Because it's the only thing I have left to do in this world. So why don't you just take a good look at one another one last time and think it over for a few minutes more. They sober up a little, look at their shoes in confusion, then step out into the hall to talk among themselves.
Good morning, Simon! Glorious day, huh? Here, have a donut. Can you lend me twenty dollars? Thanks. Where's the library in the scruffy little burgh?
answer: Down the highway about a mile and a half and then make a left.

question: Excellent! I'm polishing up the final chapters of my 'Confession' and I need a reasonably well-stocked reference section. What's this?
answer: I thought. Um. I was. I wanted to. Maybe.

question: Can I take this? I'll correct the spelling.
answer: One of you is gunna lose an eye. One of you is gunna lose an eye! One of you. I promise. You can set me on fire. But one of you is gunna have an eye torn out of your head. I promise.

question: This kinda thing has happened before.
How do you know?
Mr Fool, what is this?
Are you sure?
answer: Of course I'm sure. I corrected the spelling myself.

question: It made my daughter sing.
answer: Yeah, well, you know -- that's what poetry does.

question: We gotta talk. What the hell were you trying to do when you wrote this thing?
Well, you know you wrote it in a kind of iambic pentameter.

Verse. Look, in my opinion, this is pretty powerful stuff. Though your spelling is Neanderthal, and your reasoning a little naive, your instincts are profound. But the whole thing needs to be given a more cohesive shape. It can be expanded. Followed through. Unified. You see what I'm getting at? Are you willing to commit yourself to this? To really work on it? To give it its due? In the face of adversity and discouragement? To rise to the challenge you yourself have set? And don't gimme that wonderstruck 'I'm-only-a-humble-garbage-man' bullshit, either.
Of course it does.
Yeah. No. OK?
Don't move! Fuck. There.
Yes. Now shut up and lie back.
Yes. You gunna be alright? Here. Bite on this.
It's blood. From your head. Lie back. Shove that in your mouth and hold on to something. Okay. You ready?
So, do you have, like, you know, a girlfriend, Henry?
Do you find me attractive?
I look young for my age, don't I?
How old do you think I am?
How young?
But how... I mean, do I look more like twenty, or... you know, thirty?
Hey, Warren, are you a registered voter?
answer: Bug off, Vicky! 'Saving America From Itself.' What the fuck is this?

question: It's everything you need to know about the upcoming elections and congressman Owen Feer and all the really good things he wants to do for our country.
He wants to win back this country for us Americans, Warren, and restore some kind of cultural-moral standard to our way of life.
answer: What time's your kid go off to school?

question: Nine o'clock.
answer: How about I come over and visit you later?

question: Well, I don't know, Warren. I mean...
answer: Come on. I mean it. I'm trying to change.

question: How dare you put something like this up where anyone can see it!
It's pornography! The product of a diseased mind! You oughta be ashamed of yourself, Mr Deng!

There's no accounting for taste, is there, Mr Deng? See, Simon, there are three kinds of there. There's 'There'. T-H-E-R-E. There are the donuts. Then there's T- H-E-I-R; which is the possessive. It is their donut. Then, finally, there's 'they're'. T-H-E-Y-'-R-E. A contraction, meaning they are. They're the donut people. Get it?

And look, if you're gunna read Wordsworth you've gotta get a more up-to-date edition. This odoriferous tome you're so attached to doesn't even have all fourteen books of the Prelude. And you need notes. Commentary. I'll go to the library and find you the best edition they have.
answer: Thank you, but that's OK. I'll stop there on my way back from work. Well, yes, maybe not today, but, you know, tomorrow, probably.

question: Quit.
Yeah.
You need time to write, Simon. To study. To reflect.

We all have to make sacrifices. A vocation like ours, Simon, is not a nine to five thing. You can't put a fence around a man's soul. We think and feel where and when we can think and feel. We are the servants of our muse and we toil where she commands.
Yeah, and what's that mean?
answer: I guess it means it's not her fault.

question: You ever think of leaving?
Yeah.
Out there. You know, into the world. Where ever.
'Opportunity will step away and make room for a man to pass it by.'
No. I found it in a fortune cookie.
No. Not yet. Soon. We'll see.
Ma, you take your medication? Guess so.
What do you want?
answer: I've got these books for Simon.

question: Listen. I know a man. He's a big shot in the publishing business. Angus James. Smart, adventurous and tons of integrity. When this thing is ready, I'll recommend he reads it. He'll respect my opinion.
answer: A man was here today looking for you.

question: What man?
answer: I don't know. He drove by the house a few times.

question: Why do they torment me like this? Why? They're like a bunch of fucking mosquitoes!
answer: What do they want from you?

question: They want to suffocate me, Simon! They wanna extinguish me like a flame! They're afraid, that's why! They're afraid of what I might do! What I might say! Think! They're afraid of my ideas! You and I are alike in this way, Simon.

We're outsiders. We think and feel too much and too deeply. And the world can't handle that. Our mere existence is a threat to its illusion of security. Sure, they'll name a wing of a new library after us when we're dead! But now... Now, when we're alive... Now, they wanna burn us at the stake! Scram. For example, I made love to your mother about half an hour ago and now I'm beginning to think that maybe it wasn't such a good idea. I mean to say, I think Fay may be jealous.
answer: I don't want to think about this.

question: Bad move, Simon. A poet has got to be able to think about anything.
Simon. Hey, Simon. Come on. I got ya some coffee.
It's a computer. You write on it. Here's the manual.
I stole it. Now listen. Remember how yesterday we discussed the relative desirability of cadence in relation to the readability of...
Simon, I can't work under these conditions.
answer: Yeah! Get outta here, you freak!

question: Get a life!
Keep a look out. Tell me when he's gone.
answer: Henry, what's going on? Who is that guy? What's he want?

question: He wants to help me! He wants to be my friend.
The world. The way it is. Is this a way to help relieve suffering?
How can you be so sure?
answer: Because vocation is the difference. Only someone who really cares doubts. Listen, father, as I was about to tell my friend Simon here, I am, without doubt, the biggest sinner within a hundred miles of this parish. But still, I've gotta stay up late at night to outdo the unending parade of mundane little atrocities I see committed every day right out in the open spaces of this loud and sunlit culture we call home.

question: You seem to me to be a sensitive and generous man.
answer: I like to think so. But the fact is I appreciate depravity. Nevertheless, I insist your vocation makes a difference, because to hold out anything other than a spiritual yardstick to reality is to be jerking off grandly into the abyss. Listen, have you got any money? Let's go have a drink.

question: Right. What time's your mother get off work? Fay, are you a registered voter?
answer: Don't you dare talk that way to me! And keep your hands off my brother. Pearl, what are you doing here?

question: I'm watchin' her.
answer: You and Vicky get back together?

question: I gotta regular job now and everything.
answer: I saw this retard on TV this morning.

question: He's gunna be the next president of the United States of America, Fay.
answer: Keep dreamin' Warren. The guy's a Nazi.

question: I like him!
He's a decent man. He takes complicated issues and totally simplifies them. And I appreciate that.
No. You know what the problem is with this country, Fay? Me. I'm the problem. We live in a culture of poverty and crime, where the work ethic is undermined and male responsibility is made irrelevant.
answer: Come on, Pearl, let's go play at my house.

question: What do you mean, you quit?
Why!
answer: There are things I want to do.

question: Like what?
answer: 'Opportunity will step out of the way to let a man... pass it by.'

question: Are you drunk?
answer: Now you have to go out and get a job!

question: I am not gettin' a job! Who's gunna look after Mom!
Pearl, go outside.
answer: If you treat Mom like a sick person, she's gunna stay like... you know, a sick person.

question: Simon, don't be retarded...
answer: I am not retarded! I can see with my own eyes.

question: Mom can't be left alone with no one to keep an eye on her.
answer: Well, who's been keeping an eye on her while you've been out getting fucked by every OTB winner in town? Aggghhhh!!!

question: What happened to her, Simon? How did she get this way? Will it happen to me too? Huh? Why are we so fucked up?
Henry?
answer: Simon! What are you doing here?

question: Henry... Your parole officer, Officer Buuel, came by again today. He told me to tell you that if you don't call him they're gunna put you back in jail.
He gave me this number...
He was talking to Mr Deng too, and, well, you know, I was thinking...
answer: Simon, just shut the fuck up! Forgive me. Forgive me, Simon.

question: Call him, Henry. Please.
answer: OK. Look, do me a favor. You got a library card?

question: Yeah.
answer: Check this out for me. Milton. Seventeenth century. English. You see, Simon, it's important my 'Confession' dig up the past, comb previous evidence and help chart the historic -- even the aesthetic -- inevitability of my ideas. And... This place is crawling with chicks, Simon. Wander around. Leer a little. Cop a feel. Impose yourself on 'em. See what happens.

question: I make girls uncomfortable.
answer: Bullshit! You've got a rough hewn charm that sets 'em on edge. Now, listen, I gotta go.

question: Henry? What did you do?
What's up?
I'm creating my rsum. This computer's got a program especially for it. I bought some special stationery too. It's scented. Look. It's roses.
answer: Can you type my poem into that thing?

question: That's your poem?

I was caught. Yes, I was caught... once. I was caught in flagranti delicto screwing a thirteen-year-old girl named Susan. She was an ugly and mean-spirited kid, but she knew how to play upon my weaknesses which, I admit, are deep and many. You appear shocked.

It was a pathetic little conspiracy. A transparently desperate attempt to discredit me and my ideas; to label me a mere pedophile. As if I'd be ashamed of such a thing. As if Socrates himself hadn't been taken out of circulation for corrupting the youth of Athens! Seven years. Seven years for one afternoon of blissful transgression. But what of it? Who cares? Prison's not so bad; particularly if one's a sex offender, free from the popular and conventional horror of sodomy. They were not 'lost years'. I put them to good use. I began my major work. My opus. Believe me, Simon, this incident with the girl, prison... It pales to insignificance in the wider context of my career. Nothing in comparison to the day my 'Confession' is unleashed. What an orgy we'll have then, huh? What shouts of outrage from the offended populace, from the sanctimonious purveyors of culture and quality, the righteous defenders of what ever inane and haphazard notion of progress then in vogue. They'll be beside themselves with fiercely reasoned critical analysis. Apoplectic with indignation! Their feelings will be hurt. Yes, like a mirror which reflects only the inside of the person before it, my 'Confession' will lovingly render humanity's common monstrosity in all of its lurid wide screen glory. Why should I blush or feel shame before the common lot of humanity, anyway, for a few banal and, again I admit, inelegant transgressions? After all, really, I'm doing civilization a favor.
We are told not to judge. But to forgive. Not to look into our neighbor's eye to find the bad, but to find the good. Now this is difficult. I admit. But having a good friend is not always easy.
answer: Yes, but... do you think Henry is... dangerous?

question: He needs help. Our help. Yours especially.
Gnoc, gimme a value pack of Kleenex, will ya?
answer: The greats all say the same thing

question: Push over.
answer: As I tried to make plain in Paris

question: When were you in Paris?
answer: That's beside the point. But did they listen to me? Of course not!

question: Well, you oughta be home writing instead of hanging out over here with all your groupies.
Pardon me, swivel-hips. Is that your PowerBook?
Hello?
My name is Edna Rodriguez and I write the human interest column for the Queens County Examiner and I was just wondering if I could have a word with Simon Grim?
Thank you.
answer: You can't talk to him for, you know, too long or anything, 'cause he's gotta, you know... he writes all day. That's all he does. Can you believe that? Hey! Simon! Get down here! Simon, this is Edna. She's from the newspaper.

question: Simon, the Parents' Association at the local high school are calling your poem pornography. The teachers are defending the students' right to exercise their critical tastes and sensibilities. The county agrees with the Church and considers the poem emblematic of modern society's moral disintegration. How do you feel about these controversial reactions to your poem?
We all thought he was retarded.
Never said a word.
Had no friends.

Dear Mr Grim, we here at the magazine consider ourselves and the publication open-minded and cutting edge and have consistently printed the work of the most brilliant and farseeing young talent of the day. Every week we are forced to return writing which we can not for one reason or another publish and include a brief but polite refusal. But this tract you've sent us demands a response as violent as the effect your words have had upon us. Drop dead. Keep your day job. Sincerely, The Editors.
You can't argue with taste?
answer: About taste. You can't argue about taste. God, Simon.

question: The other twenty-five are almost as bad. I don't know why I bother.
answer: What do you mean you don't know why you bother? You bother because you know the poem is excellent!

question: Do I?
I'm not so sure sometimes.
answer: Can you sit there, look me straight in the eye, and tell me you don't think this poem is great? That it is not at once a work of great lyrical beauty and ethical depth? That it is not a genuine, highly individual, and profound meditation on the miracle of existence?

question: I, ah...
No. I can't.
answer: So, you see, you have no choice!

question: Can you recommend it to your friend, the publisher? Henry? Can you recommend the poem to him? I mean, I think it's finished and, for better or worse, it is book length.
answer: That might not be as easy as it seems.

question: Why?
answer: Well, it's been a long time. My name might not carry as much weight as it once did with Angus.

question: But he's your friend, right?
answer: We were close at one time.

question: You said he respected your opinion.
answer: Look, Simon, opinions come and go. To be honest; my ideas, my writing, they haven't always been received well or even calmly. They're upsetting. I'm a controversial man. You see, what I'm doing is too radical. Too uncompromising. It'll take time for people to see its value. It's ahead of its time, perhaps, or maybe just... A recommendation from me might do you as much harm as it does good.

question: Henry, why can't I read the 'Confession'?
answer: Because certain work needs to be experienced all at once in order for one to appreciate the full force of its character.

question: Simon, wake up! The guy's in a dream world!
answer: He's afraid that his reputation will prevent people from giving my work an honest chance.

question: His reputation as what?
Gimme a break.
answer: He's kinda like in exile. Marginalized on account of his ideas.

question: If he's such a great big fat genius, why doesn't he write books? Like you do.
answer: He has. He's written a book. It's almost completed. He's been working on it for years. It's just not published.

question: Yeah, I bet. It's probably disgusting.
answer: It's a quite serious and difficult piece of work, apparently.

question: Have you read it?
answer: No. Not yet. Soon. Certain work needs to be experienced all at once in order for one to appreciate the full force of its character.

question: Hi, I'll take that. Aren't you the messenger?
Are you here to fix the plumbing?
answer: I'm here to see Mr. Angus James.

question: Are you?
answer: I'm not a plumber. Or a messenger. I was once a garbage man. But now I'm a poet.

question: It won't be television!
Angus, look, we have a number of charts here...
answer: In every home in America the PC will be where the TV used to be.

question: And it'll be a direct connection to all forms of media.
answer: An unprecedented transformation of American social life...

question: Hello, and why do you think I should take valuable time out of my busy schedule to read... This?
Really?
Get him a coffee, Laura.
Hold my calls for the next half hour.

In the infinite amplitude of his love, God wants to create the largest number of best elements that can exist together in one cosmos... OK. In an instantaneous calculation made in eternity, God computes the best possible world and creates it. Fine. This 'decision' by God is uncontingent and eternal rather than temporally or ontologically sequential.
What?
O-N-T... Don't you have some kinda spell-check on that thing?

It is impossible for every perfect good to be compatible with every other perfect good. The intense beauty of the mountain must be set off by the fertility of the plain, so to speak. The good of freewill must entail real choices for sin. Listen, Amy, back off. I'm on parole.
answer: You feel the same way. I can tell. I can see it when you look at me.

question: Hey! I don't look at you.
answer: Yes you do. In the street. In the parking lot yesterday. That night on the highway.

question: I look at a lot of people that way.
No, as a matter of fact, I think you're a real bright kid and I like that about you.

This is really quite unbelievably bad, my friend. I mean, I'm all for experimentation and I've made a career out of a healthy disregard for convention, but... Look, this is profoundly irrelevant material. This is only my opinion. But it's an opinion I value highly. Goodnight, Laura. Call Norton Press. We're still on for tomorrow. I've been wrong before as a publisher. But I refuse to admit I've ever been wrong as a reader. You have talent, I admit. You have an innate sense of the musicality of language. A good ear, maybe. But you do nothing significant with it. And this twisted reasoning that poses as... conviction or insight, it's... well, it's embarrassing. Why did you bring this thing to me, anyway?
answer: A friend of mine spoke of you. He said you had a lot of integrity.

question: Yes, well, of course, I do. But I'm not crazy, am I? Who is this person? Do I know him?
Henry, put those magazines back.
answer: I'm just looking at the pictures.

question: It's not good for you.
answer: I learn so much from these magazines, Mr Deng. I refuse to discriminate between modes of knowing.

question: And you can't smoke in here anymore.
It's the law.
answer: This place is losing all its charm, Mr Deng.

question: Business is good. The kids, they hang out all day and drink coffee, talk about art and read poetry.
answer: It's just a fad, Mr Deng. These kids today, they're just slaves to fashion.

question: That can't be right! And so what? My credit's good.
Hey, Warren, you gotta couple of bucks I can borrow?
answer: Listen, Henry, I wanna remind you to vote this Thursday.

question: Ah, yes, of course. When noble minds shrink from the task of leadership scoundrels will rush in to fill the void. Thanks.
answer: It's every American's right. A blessing. Yet another opportunity to save America from itself.

question: Henry?
What kind of... Well, I mean... What kind of... perverse things would you do to me?
No, really.
Same time.
Same time.
Same time.
Same time.
Same time.
Same time.
Same time.
So I was a janitor! So what?
answer: But Angus James said he didn't even know you!

question: Well, I mean, we weren't like bosom buddies or anything. But we used to talk sometimes. In the elevator. In the morning. He said he liked my ideas. Being a janitor's a good job if you're a writer. Especially the night shift; all that time to think and develop my ideas.
answer: Do it. Anyway, he hated my poem.

question: Well, what the hell does he know? He wouldn't know a vital piece of literary art if it came up and bit him in the leg. To hell with him! He's not the only publisher in the world!
It's true. A prophet is seldom heeded in his own land. Remember that.
Hey, look, treasure! What is this?
It's a ring. Jewelry.
answer: I think it's a gasket. A fitting from off of that old refrigerator over there.

question: Hey, Warren, I found Pearl wandering around by the garbage dump.
Who lost?
Oh. Well, you know. Somebody's gotta lose.
answer: What's the fucking use. You make sacrifices. You try to be a decent human being. Try to contribute something meaningful to society. And what happens? They lose to a bunch of cultural elite liberal fuck-ups. I don't give a shit anymore. People deserve what they get.

question: Vicky? What happened to you?
answer: He's a good man, Henry. Nobody's perfect.

question: I guess not.
I found Pearl wandering around with no shoes on her feet.
And you don't?
Hello, Fay.
You gotta get outta the house, Fay. You can't blame yourself for not being here. You did all you could for her.
You got the Internet on that contraption?
Look Fay, about, you know, between us -- what happened...
answer: I don't wanna talk about it, Henry!

question: Type a part of Simon's poem onto the Internet.
Go ahead.
Why not?
Come on, Fay. It's a great idea.
answer: I don't know if he would want us to do that.

question: Sure he would. Just the first ten verses.
He'll thank you for it later.
Gimme another one of those tall double espressos, Mr Deng.
I'm just looking.
There's this fascinating story about a famous rock band and how they tied a friend of theirs to a bed in their hotel room and inserted a live fish into her vagina. They say she had numerous orgasms.
answer: Henry, you need to do something with your life. Get a job, or something.

question: I mean, it wasn't the entire fish, it was just, you know, the nose. The nose of the fish. You don't find that interesting?
You ever wonder what it would be like to have sex with an animal, Mr Deng?
answer: That coffee is free. Just take it and get out of here.

question: Did you see him?
Did you talk?
You've got to tell him, Fay.
Henry?
answer: Simon, I don't feel so good.

question: What's wrong?
answer: I feel all kinda clammy. And damp.

question: How many of these did you have?
Henry, we have to talk.
Fay's taking a shower.
answer: How much you think I can get for this?

question: I, Henry, take you, Fay to be my wife.
answer: I, Henry, take you, Fay to be my wife.

question: And do promise before God and these witnesses...
answer: And do promise before God and these witnesses...

question: To be your loving and faithful husband.
answer: To be your loving and faithful husband.

question: In plenty and in want.
In joy and in sorrow.
In sickness and in health.
For as long as we both shall live.
answer: For as long as we both shall live.

question: Bless, O Lord, this ring, that he who gives it and she who wears it may abide in your peace and continue in your favor until their life's end. Whom God has joined, let no man separate.
I'm willing to negotiate, Simon.
You've had other offers.
What?
Because I think your writing will be tremendously successful.
It's growing on me.
answer: What made you change your mind?

question: What were the terms?
answer: A hundred thousand in cash up front.

question: Royalties?
Well, that could be better. But it is a hundred thousand dollars up front. Guaranteed money. You could use that.
Of course it's good.

I've let myself down, Simon! I've let myself be caught in the bloody maw of banal necessity! How did I get here? How did this happen to me? I'm going to be somebody's father! I need time to think. To write. Time to finish my 'Confession'! I can't work for a living! It's impossible! I tried once. My genius will be wasted trying to make ends meet! This is how great men topple, Simon. Their hearts are in the right place too much of the time! They get sidetracked! Distracted. Oh! How could I have been so careless!
answer: Henry, please, let me read the 'Confession'.

question: No. Not now. It's not done. I'm all washed up. I'm finished!
answer: Angus James is convinced my poem is going to make him incredibly wealthy. He'll read your book and seriously consider publishing it. If I ask him to. I'm certain.

question: Really? You really think so?
answer: I'll insist he publish the 'Confession'. Or I won't let him publish my poem.

question: You'd do that? You'd do that for me?
Do you realize what you're saying?
It's terrible.
Yes.
answer: And you want me to consider publishing it?

question: Yes.
Yes.
answer: Simon, this book, it's... It's really quite bad.

question: That's what you said about my poem.
answer: I'm offering you a very real expression of my faith in your writing. Two hundred thousand dollars and a sixty/forty split.

question: But just exactly what is the nature of your faith in my writing?
answer: Look, Simon, you don't require my admiration. You require my experience as a publisher. And that experience leads me to believe your poem will make more money than any book of poetry ever published. In history. Virtually make you a household name within two years. You'll never have to work on a garbage truck again, I assure you. Or do anything else for that matter. Whereas this 'Confession' by Henry Fool... The most I can say for this is... The man is a scoundrel.

question: He taught me everything I know.
answer: No! He encouraged all that was expressive in you to become manifest. He inspired you to act. He influenced your perception.

question: How about if my advance is only a hundred thousand?
We could split the royalties seventy/thirty.
answer: I will not publish Henry Fool's 'Confession'. Will you sign the contract?

question: Simon? You're here.
It's a boy.
She's alright. Thanks. How did it go?
answer: Listen, Henry, Angus James didn't like your 'Confession'.

question: Ah. I see. Well, what now?
Did he suggest changes?
I mean, after all, there are things I can do to make it more accessible.

I can soften up some of the language and make it read easier. Take out some of the more intratextual references and popularize the underlying Sturm und Drang, so to speak. I can change its mode. Make it more of a conventional novel instead.
Oh, Simon, don't be such a purist! I appreciate your protectiveness, but the integrity of the work gives it a durability that can sustain such things.
What are you saying; that it doesn't merit revision?
answer: I'm saying... Angus James didn't like it.

question: Well, did you tell him what you think?
Yes, it does. You've got to use your influence with him.
answer: I gave it to him to read and he hated it. What more can I do?

question: You can refuse to let him publish your poem.
You said you would.
answer: That was before I read your book.

question: Oh.
answer: I signed the contract, Henry. Look, Henry, what did you expect?

question: I... I don't know. Honesty, perhaps.
answer: Look, if I had told you, when at first I read it, that I thought it was no good, what would you have done?

question: I would have respected your opinion.
answer: And insisted that there's no accounting for taste.

question: Well, is there?
answer: I don't know. I didn't bring it to Angus because I thought it was good. I brought it to Angus because you're my friend.

question: Oh how perfectly enormous of you, Simon.
answer: Look, Henry, I did it! I wrote. I wrote poetry because you told me to! I worked! I worked while you sat back and comfortably dismissed the outside world as too shallow, stupid and mean to appreciate your ideas.

question: Is that such a priority? Is that some sort of measure of a man's worth? To drag what's best in him out into the street so every average slob with some pretense to taste can poke it with a stick?

You must be pretty impressed with yourself, huh? The all too obviously talented new man, the important new voice, the early clue to a new direction, or whatever, etc., etc., etc! A popular new trend conveniently packaged for the distracted young herd! You want to be liked more than you know, Simon Grim! You'd be nowhere without me and you know it.
Yes. It's time you left. I saw you for what you were in the beginning, Simon. I hold no grudge and I'm certain you will, in time, leave some serious and small dent in this world.
answer: The world is full of shit.

question: Say hello to Patty, Ned.
So what did you learn at school today, Ned? Anything? Here, I'll teach you something. Horrible, isn't it?
That's it. That's it. Perfect!
answer: Hey, Fool, it's about your friend -- what's his name. Your brother-in- law.

question: What about him?
answer: The controversial and reclusive American poet Simon Grim has been awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature. The Swedish Academy, who will confer the award late next week, praised Mr Grim for works of great and difficult striving, for the rendering of the desperate, the ugly and the mundane in a language packed with our shared human frailties...

question: God, they must be hard up for geniuses to pin medals on because, listen, I gotta tell you, when I first met this guy he didn't even know what an iambic pentameter was.
Keep a lid on it, Bill, you're outta your league.
answer: Stir things up so as to stay in the newspapers. That's his racket.

question: He's a great American poet, you dumb fuck!
answer: Poet, my ass! I could puke all over a piece a loose leaf and be more profound than he is!

question: Come over here and say that and I'll cripple ya in three different ways, you boozed-up Philistine!
answer: Henry! Listen, you degenerate, I've had about enough of this! Ned, have you been drinking?

question: His throat hurt from smoking.
answer: Henry, don't come home tonight! I'm warning you! Don't come home at all! Ever!

question: Who's winning?
What's going on in there?
answer: We gotta have rock 'n' roll shows these days, Henry. The poetry readings just don't pay the bills no more.

question: What did I tell you! It was just a fad. I told you that! I told everyone!
answer: Did you hear about Simon? It was on the news today.

question: Yeah yeah yeah. So what? A Nobel Prize. Anybody can get one of them these days. That's the problem, with this world, Mr Deng... Nobody's got any standards anymore. You seen Fay?
answer: You better sleep in my office tonight, Henry. She was very angry. You've gotta let her cool off.

question: I can't sleep in there with that racket!
What are you doing here, Pearl?
Some what? Shit!
answer: Come sit here. That's what my dad always says.

question: What?
answer: 'You want some?' People say you were once in jail for having sex with a girl my age.

question: That was a long time ago.
You oughta get outta here, Pearl.
Go home.
Fine.
Why not?
Warren beat up your mom? Is she alright?
Does she need help?
answer: I'll suck your cock if you kill him for me.

question: It is true your husband served seven years in prison for statutory rape.
And when was that?
answer: That was... I dunno. Fifteen... Sixteen years ago.

question: And when were you married?
answer: We were married seven years ago.

question: Were you aware at all of the victim's relationship with his daughter?
The girl, the daughter, Pearl. She had been having sexual relations with her father.
Mom?
Where's Dad?
answer: I don't know, honey. Leave me alone a minute, I gotta think.

question: Mom?
Is Dad in trouble?
answer: Yes, Ned, he is. He's in big trouble. Now just be quiet for two minutes.

question: Mom?
Mom, can I be a mailman when I grow up?
answer: Sure you can, honey. You can be anything you want.

question: Yeah, what do you want?
What's his name?
There ain't no one here by that name.
This is post marked five years ago. What does he look like?
I'll see you in Stockholm.
answer: Look, Simon, the world's a scary place. I admit it. But it's not my fault. I swear!

question: I'm sorry, Henry.
answer: Don't be. You had things to do.

question: Passport and ticket, please. It's an honor to meet you, Mr Grim. Really. I mean, God. Congratulations on the Nobel Prize.
I know all your work by heart. It changed my life.
